catentdesc.name: Snow Peas
catentdesc.longdescription: Popular in stir fries and added to salads for extra crunch. Snow peas are versatile and are great eaten raw or even steamed. A tasty member of the legume family.

catentdesc.name: Leaf Lettuce
catentdesc.longdescription: Leafy and chock full of nutrients, perfect on any sandwich or in salads. Lettuce's mild flavor works great to counterbalance other stronger ingredients. Wash lightly and eat raw.

catentdesc.name: Assorted Peppers
catentdesc.longdescription: Add some color and texture to your salads. Great in fajitas, chilli and other southern cuisine. Green peppers have a slightly bitter flavor, while red, orange and yellow peppers are sweeter with an almost fruity essence.

catentdesc.name: Cucumbers
catentdesc.longdescription: Add some freshness to a salad with cucumbers. Great for pickling with dill and garlic. High in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory properties.

catentdesc.name: Onions
catentdesc.longdescription: The building block for all stews, soups and salads. Great eaten raw or cooked. Just try not to cry while cutting them!

catentdesc.name: Red Potatoes
catentdesc.longdescription: High in iron and essential minerals. Great baked, scalloped, mashed or cut into fries. Potatoes are a staple at any dinner table.

catentdesc.name: Tomatoes
catentdesc.longdescription: Great for salads or sauces. High in antioxidants, vitamins and nutrients. Tomatoes are great for the cardiovascular system.

catentdesc.name: Broccoli
catentdesc.longdescription: Enjoy broccoli raw with your favorite dip, steamed, or tossed it into a stir-fry. Broccoli is a great source of dietary fiber and vitamins C, K and A. Eating broccoli can help prevent heart disease.

catentdesc.name: Carrots
catentdesc.longdescription: Carrots are rich in dietary fiber, antioxidants, beta-carotene and Vitamin A. Carrots really do help you see better in the dark! Along with all of the health benefits, carrots make a delicious healthy snack.

catentdesc.name: Large Eggplant
catentdesc.longdescription: Eggplants are naturally high in antioxidants and free radicals, which are known to help prevent cancer and lower cholesterol. Eggplants are popular in Middle Eastern and Italian cuisine. As eggplant can be somewhat bitter raw, it is recommended to soak it in salted water to remove the bitterness and prepare it for cooking.

catentdesc.name: Red Cabbage
catentdesc.longdescription: High in fiber, Vitamins A, C, E and B. Cabbage's high antioxiHelps boost the your immune system. Great for soups, cabbage rolls, sauerkraut and kimchee.
